Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: High-precision triple-isotopologue analysis of N2
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nitrogen fixation by humans, for agricultural and industrial use, has increased tenfold since the beginning of the 20th century. This profound perturbation to the nitrogen cycle has revealed that the links between the global nitrogen cycle and the biosphere are more complex than previously thought. To improve the understanding of these links at the global scale, investigators will develop a new tracer for the nitrogen cycle that exploits natural co-variations in 14N14N, 14N15N, and 15N15N.

These three isotopologues of N2 comprise a tracer that is fundamentally sensitive to processes that alter N-N bonds such as nitrogen fixation and N2 production. Through a combination of laboratory measurements, field measurements, and experiments involving microbes, investigators will characterize the basic biogeochemistry of these species that is relevant to atmospheric and oceanic settings. These measurements will test whether N2 triple-isotopologue analysis can be applied more broadly to constrain nitrogen cycling on local and global scales. The scientific findings will be disseminated during conference presentations and in peer-reviewed publications.

This project will also integrate research and education through the training of a female graduate student from a traditionally underrepresented group, supporting her training in a biogeochemistry short course. In addition, a series of short animations about nitrogen will be produced in partnership with the popular PHD TV YouTube channel. They will highlight how nitrogen has played a larger role in society than is often unrecognized, weaving together human history, biogeochemistry, and climate science in an approachable comic-animation medium that has become the hallmark of PHD TV.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The activities associated with this project resulted in several key discoveries relevant to the atmospheric chemistry and biogeochemistry of nitrogen, one of the most important ingredients of life. First, the first high-precision measurements of atmospheric 15N15N  reveal that its proportions are significantly higher in the atmosphere than what biological or geological processes can yield. Laboratory experiments suggest that upper-atmospheric chemistry causes this unique atmospheric 15N15N enrichment. Such unique atmospheric and biological "signatures" allow the community to trace biological and geological nitrogen cycling as they occur in the natural environment. Unlike earlier methods, the tracers based on naturally occurring 15N15N molecules do not require nutrient amendments or incubations and may avoid the associated methodological biases. Proof-of-principle studies were performed showing how these new tracers can be applied from the scale of an agricultural plot (i.e. for evaluating soil health) to the scale of a planet (e.g. for assessing the rates of global nitrogen cycling). These latter findings may be of particular utility for societal needs.

The findings build upon recent NSF-supported analytical innovations, which have resulted in new tracers in biogeochemistry. The results were disseminated to the broader scientific community through presentations at universities, conferences, public lectures, as well as peer-reviewed publications and forthcoming book chapters. A female postdoctoral scholar was mentored as part of this project, after which she began an independent research career in academia. In addition, an international collaboration was established between the principal investigators and environmental microbiologists at Radboud University in the Netherlands for current and future laboratory work on microbial isotopic biosignatures.
